content: DIABETES MELLITUS Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease in which blood sugar levels are abnormally high because either the body doesn’t produce enough insulin or the body is resistance to the insulin produced, or both the 2 process happens at the same time. It is a disease of global health importance associated with high deaths rates and complications. In 2019 alone it was estimated that around a half a billion people worldwide had it. From 2009 to 2019, the number increased from 285 million to 463million, that an increase of 62%. Half of the 463million with Diabetes do not know they have it. Majority of those who don’t know that they have it are found in low and middle income countries, that is Botswana included. In Africa over two-thirds (66.7) of people with diabetes are unaware they have the disease. To bring the issue closer to home, the World Health Organization in 2019 reported that 6% of Botswana population had diabetes. Among scary issues were that 43% of our population is overweight while 19.5% was obese. The same organisation pointed out that 24.5% of our population was physically inactive.  In 2017 Mwita etal established that of the patients admitted in Princess Marina Hospital for acute heart failure 12.4% of the didn’t know they had diabetes compared to 15.5% who knew they had diabetes. In Botswana 32 per 1000 have diabetes but do not know they have it. It is on this background that Batswana need to be sensitized about Diabetes and further be encouraged to test for diabetes at any nearest health facility countrywide. #AwarenessWednesday #CampaignAgainstDiabetes Contributor: Dr Gomolemo Tiego
comment: Diabetes is the most expensive health care industry in the world.

content: Worst things to do after a workout   Excluding fast-acting carbs It is of vital importance to quickly consume the proper nutrients after a workout, and carbs play a very important role in this equation. Since the body is primed to absorb carbohydrates to refill muscle glycogen after lifting weights, it’s best to take in the “fast-acting” or “high-GI” variety. Foods like white rice, white potatoes, rice cakes, and bagels will get into the bloodstream rapidly, which will elevate insulin levels and allow you to push nutrients into cells at a very fast rate.
comment: Eating with diabetes is a problem.

content: As he gets older he needs more and more insulin. His pod ran out of insulin today and before he could eat dinner we had to put a new one on. (He needs insulin for virtually everything he eats.) He draws the insulin, fills the pod, pairs his loop system and inserts the cannula  all by himself most days (with my supervision). Some days he wants my help and I gladly oblige ...other days he does it on his own. Today is a “I want help day” and that’s just fine by me. First, we look around his body to see where this insertion should go based on where his last one was, where his dexcom is, what he’s going to do for the next few days, and what his general feeling of what area of his body he wants to use. Then I prep his skin and squeeze the area around the pod and we joke around to try to distract him as it inserts.  We are a team. Some days  we need more and some days we need less from our teammates but the one constant is that the other person is always there to meet you right where you are that day.  #weneedacure #empathynotpity #support
comment: self care is a great choice for all of us.

content: Crazy Hypo Episodes Hi All, I was diagnosed as type 2 about 4 months ago after a nasty episode requiring a week in ICU. I was put on Lantus for long acting and Humalog for short. Steadily I seemed to be needing less Humalog. I keep going hypo down to 34 but most consistently in the low 40s. So I stopped taking Humalog a couple of days ago. I am still taking the prescribed dose of Lantus and still crashing. May stop the Lantus too and see how I feel. This crashing is exhausting and scary. I don’t know if this has happened to any of you, but some insight would really help, feeling alone in this.
comment: Low blood sugar can be serious.

content: I ran out of humalog today and can’t get the prescription filled until tomorrow when dr calls in rx.  The pharmacist called me to tell me that Walmart has an otc fast acting “similar “ insulin for $35.  (I’ve heard of this but would prefer to chat with doc about it before I go off grid to Walmart)  She told me they have something similar at Walgreens fir $150. (But I think she said I’d still need an rx) My pharmacist told me that humalog is very expensive.  With my insurance I pay $30 per refill.   I asked her how much it would be without insurance.  $1400 per refill!!! $1400 per refill!!!!!!!  That’s generally once a month  Let’s sipher that out per year  If my “naughts “ are in the right place in my head . ... that’s $16,800 per year plus the little pins to get it into your body.  ($45 per box without insurance ... $30 with)  Dear Lord ... we need help!!!
comment: Insulin is a serious problem for people with diabetes and one of the most expensive issues in the world.

content: Humalog now available for $35. Find out if you qualify. ↓
comment: Insulin is a serious problem for people with diabetes and one of the most expensive issues in the world.

content: It finally happened. 🙄 My skin is super irritated from my #dexcomg6 (slide to see the picture)  - - A lot of my friends from my #type1community have experienced similar issues unfortunately. The best way I can describe how it feels is a burn. I knew it was tender and I couldn’t lay on my right side or it would hurt badly and I guess while I was sleeping I just ripped it off. 🤷🏻‍♀️ I made sure to clean it and put some antibacterial cream on it but DANG it hurts! 🥺 - - REALLY hoping this won’t be a common occurrence now. 🙏🏼 — #type1diabetic #diabetic #dexcomg6 #adhesivetape #adhesivereaction #chronicillness #insulin #multipledailyinjections #humalog #toujeo💉 #thatdiabeticlife #t1dlookslikeme #mom #girlmom #missourimom #girlgang #christianblogger #christianfamily
comment: Diabetes is a dangerous crisis in the world of health care.

content: Millions of Americans with diabetes use insulin regularly—but what are the differences between these two common options?
comment: Insulin is a high-income, high-income thing.

content: A few big name insulins, Novolog and Humalog, have recently gone generic which is big news for millions of Americans.  The cost of insulin can be a significant expense so if you know someone who is currently taking insulin, especially Novolog or Humalog, be sure to let them know. Hopefully they can save a little on their prescription expenses!
comment: Insulin is a very high-income health care system.

content: Heide-marie Martin asks: How do type 1’s get great control with multiple daily injections? or just DMI’s? I used Lantus and Humalog in the beginning. I always was active but Doc had me on 25-30 U of Lantus. I went low so often I gained 30 pounds in a month due to correcting lows. I loved the insulin pens and often wonder how to get great control, lose weight or maintain a healthy weight and not go low all day long. Less long acting insulin?
comment: Diabetes is a dangerous condition that makes it hard for people to use the meds that they need.

content: Lilly has released a new supposedly faster acting mealtime insulin, Lyumjev. It is just Humalog with a vasodilator added. The data in the official FDA label suggests it is just a little faster than Humalog. It made a tiny difference in control in the clinical studies used to get it approved.  It will be, supposedly, available for $35/month. The link below provides the official FDA Label. It is telling to me that they don't graph the activity curve of Lyumjev against that of Humalog. They do chart the difference in A1c in test subjects taking it, which I have attached.    https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2020/761109s000lbl.pdf
